clinical_study.brief_title: Safety of Anticoagulant Therapy After Variceal Band Ligation
clinical_study.official_title: Safety of Anticoagulant Therapy After Variceal Band Ligation in Cirrhotic Variceal Bleeding Patients With Portal Vein Thrombosis

brief_summary.textblock: Our study is aimed to clarify the safety of anticoagulant therapy after variceal band ligation for cirrhotic variceal bleeding patients with portal vein thrombosis.

detailed_description.textblock: Variceal bleeding is one of the most serious complications of liver cirrhosis and is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) aggravates portal hypertension and worsens hemorrhage, which Increases the risk of endoscopic therapy, and PVT has been shown to be associated with a longer time to variceal eradication, a higher risk of variceal relapse and rebleeding. So, PVT should be treated earlier. Anticoagulant therapy is the main therapy but its safety is unkown，especially for variceal bleeding patients who have undergone variceal band ligation. Our purpose is to clarify its safety.

primary_outcome.description: a new hematemesis or melaena after a period of 24h of stable vital signs and hemoglobin levels

secondary_outcome.description: death from all causes of illness related to liver dysfunction

arm_group.description: low molecular weight heparin subcutaneously every 12ths for 6 months or for 14 days followed by warfarin orally with a initial dosage of 3mg daily for 5.5 months

intervention.intervention_name: low molecular weight heparin and/or warfarin
intervention.description: low molecular weight heparin and/or warfarin was given. When using warfarin, international normalized ratio (INR) was detected every 3-4 days and adjusted carefully by 0.75mg dosage until achieve the target level of 2-3.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- clinical diagnosis of cirrhosis
- Portal hypertension with esophageal variceal bleeding
- diagnosis of PVT by imaging examination
- undergo variceal band ligation
Exclusion Criteria:
- liver cancer or other tumors
- cavernous transformation of portal vein
- creatinine more than 20mg/dL，platelet count lower than 10*10^9/L
- ongoing antithrombotic treatment or have received thrombolytic treatment
- pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Having contraindications for endoscopic therapy
- Severe heart and lung diseases，uncontrolled massive hemorrhage or general infection
- major surgery within 3 months
- primary thrombophilia, Budd-Chiari syndrome
- Having received endoscopic therapy, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) or liver transplantation before
